AB

comment.author: 53922404@N05
comment._content: The coupe ute looks like a 1938-40 Chevrolet, Holden-bodied - the teardrop quards and the headlights not being set into the guards or the grill being the clues I'm going on. By 1941-46 headlights were set into the guards, from mid 1930s on Ford light commercials. The truck facing the ute is no earlier than mid to late 30s, the truck behind it possibly late 20s to early 1930s.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: From the blurb for another picture of Jones Wharf in the State Records NSW dated "c.1/1/1946" - "Number 10 wharf Jones Bay with early construction work on Number 7/8 wharf. ... " The photo in question seems to be a little later in 1946, with more work completed. Ed. Now on flickr in a large size - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/6104228461/]

comment.author: 53922404@N05
comment._content: Looking at the 1943 Sydney aerial photos on the Land Dept. SIX Viewer there are no wharves under construction in Jones Bay at that date.

comment.author: 53922404@N05
comment._content:
Is  Wharf 7/8 the one under construction with the floating crane to the east of the wharf in the centre of the Jones Bay wharf, Pyrmont photo? In the 1943 Sydney aerial photo that wharf appears completed and functional with a ship tied up there. Could the date on the "c.1/1/1946" - "Number 10 wharf Jones Bay with early construction work on Number 7/8 wharf. ... " be out by 3 or 4 years?

At least the date of the coupe ute at 1938 gives a not-older-than date for the photo but what is the not-taken-after date?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/53922404@N05] This gets more interesting ....  I worked out the intricacies of the Six Viewer (not easy - requires plugins, and the Lands Department has Darling Island in the wrong place - what hope is there if they don't know?!).

The wharf in question No.10 is really in PYRMONT Bay (not Jones) - see the angle of the Harbour Bridge - and shows up on the 1943 aerial with a jagged eastern side as on the other photo. The building in the foreground with the tower and pyramid roof is discernible.  As you slide over to the current view, the wharves' shape changes considerably.  They built all that since 1943, and these two photos are a record of the progress.  I do not know how the 7/8 wharves were numbered (yet), but Wharf 10 is still marked as such on Google Maps

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: Here is the view of the Bridge from Pyrmont Bay www.flickr.com/photos/mich2009/6132117357/in/photostream and here is the view from Jones Bay wharf www.flickr.com/photos/mich2009/6132664186/in/photostream/ Unless the Harbour Bridge has been re-oriented, the 1940's photo does not look like it was made at Jones Bay

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: Observe the angle of the Harbour Bridge in the top photo above. Now look at this view of Jones Bay with Jones Bay wharf on the left and Darling island on the right www.flickr.com/photos/mich2009/6132664186/in/photostream/ Now look at this view taken at the corner of Pyrmont Bay outside the casino. www.flickr.com/photos/mich2009/6132117357/in/photostream/ The angle of the Harbour Bridge view would suggest that the photo at the top of this page was taken at Pyrmont Bay. The configuration of the railway also suggests this to me.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: So many angles and windows open - I'm getting confused! Could this be Darling Island Wharf which today is a Doltone House venue? See page 15 of www.shfa.nsw.gov.au/content/library/documents/FB43C542-0F... www.whereis.com/nsw/pyrmont/darling-island-rd#session=MTE= -AG

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw] Ha ha - the links are very confusing!  No, this photo is not Darling Island but the next finger south-east.  Marked on the map (your 2nd link above) as Foxtel, Maritime Heritage Centre,  and importantly Wharf 10.  In all the extensions, reclamations, renames, and rebuilds, it seems that Wharf 10 is a constant.  The narrow angle of the Harbour Bridge proves that it is not in Jones Bay, but Pyrmont Bay.

There seems to be more space on the wharf in this photo than in the 1943 aerial photo,  so it must be after 1943.  And of course later than the "c.1946" photo.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
Yep - there does seem to be a few too many similarities for this not to be Pyrmont Bay wharf 10 and a post 1946 date seems to be the consensus.
Thanks to all!
-AG
